results.title: The Story of the serials
results.creator_credit: Sterling Educational Films, Saul J. Turell and Paul Killiam
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
Excerpts from famous silent serials - including “The Perils of Pauline” and even earlier productions - succeed in recapturing the atmosphere of those early thrillers. Narrated by Paul Killiam.

results.title: The Story of the pirates
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International and Brian Cosgrove
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Magic ball”
Presents a fantasy about a boy who is transported to the high seas by a magic ball. Shows how he joins with an old fisherman in foiling the attempts of a group of pirates to bury their treasure. For primary grades.

results.title: The Story of the Olympics
results.creator_credit: Conrad Television Associates and Derek Conrad
results.brief_description: This video will delight anyone with a love of sport or a general interest in the history of one of the world’s greatest sporting events. From as early as the first Olympic marathon which was won, appropriately enough by a Greek water-carrier, to as recent as the Seoul 1988, when the return of the Russians pushed the United States into third place and the drugs issue made headlines a Ben Johnson was stripped of his medal, you can relive the triumph and the heartache that have combined to make the Olympics the inspiration that they are today.

results.title: The Story of the letter post
results.creator_credit: General Post Office, Oswald Skilbeck and David Morphet
results.brief_description: this film recounts the gradual development of the British mail service from the fifteenth century, reconstructed with period costumes, museum pieces, and old stamps. Early use of messengers and Henry VIII’s service expanded for public use by Charles I; 1660 Act of Parliament; Ralph Allan’s reforms; the Industrial Revolution; improved roads and the mail coach; Rowland Hill’s penny post and modern mechanical methods.

results.title: The Story of the Kelly gang (1906)
results.creator_credit: John Tait, Nevin Tait and Charles Tait
results.brief_description: Featuring highlights from the bushranging career of the Kelly brothers, this 1906 film openly presents the Kelly’s as gallant heroes, with the police as the enemy, and makes no attempt to apologise for the cheerful celebration of outlawry. In the spirit of myth making, the film refrains from humiliating Ned by showing his execution (an obligatory display of a just reward in later films) and the film closes on a note of sadness with his capture by the police. Cast includes Elizabeth Tait, John Tait.

results.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
results.brief_description: Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour.

constellations_primary.name: Outlawed
constellations_primary.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

constellations_other.name: True blue, true crime
constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

results.description:
Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour. But it wasn’t just the longest film by time: it was literally ‘the longest film ever made’, at a staggering 4,000 feet of celluloid.

Its popularity was also staggering, so much so that in 1914 the New South Wales government banned the production of bushranger films, believing that The Story of the Kelly Gang influenced rising crime. That’s debatable, but the film’s influence on other filmmakers isn’t.
description_for_label:
Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour. But it wasn’t just the longest film by time: it was literally ‘the longest film ever made’, at a staggering 4,000 feet of celluloid.

Its popularity was also staggering, so much so that in 1914 the New South Wales government banned the production of bushranger films, believing that The Story of the Kelly Gang influenced rising crime. That’s debatable, but the film’s influence on other filmmakers isn’t.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.

results.title: The Story of the grandfather clock
results.creator_credit: Granada Television International and Brian Cosgrove
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Magic ball”
Sam noticed that the grandfather clock had stopped. The magic ball made him very small and he went through the keyhole of the clock. There he saw people.

results.title: The Story of the Bees
results.creator_credit: Moscow Technical Film Studios and Andrei Vinnitsky
results.brief_description: A fascinating story of life inside the wild bees’ hive, revealing details which only the camera can show of the organisation and care of the hive and the queen. “The Story of the bees” is a shortened version of a film entitled “Sunny tribe” which was designed to show that bees are guided by instinct, not by reason. “Sunny tribe” won an award at the Cannes International Film Festival in 1946.

results.title: The Story of Tasmania
results.brief_description: A description of the island of Tasmania, giving something of its history, geography, agriculture and main industries; including discovery and settlement; physical environment; pastoral industries; agricultural, mining, timber and fishing industries; main cities and towns; and Tasmania’s railway system. Narrated by Roger Climpson.
